message.content: We refer to medical guidelines for help. The American Diabetes Association (ADA) recommends annual measurement of blood pressure for all patients with diabetes, and more frequently if the patient has hypertension or other risk factors for cardiovascular disease. Therefore, the physician has to measure the patient’s blood pressure because it is a standard of care for any person with diabetes mellitus who presents for a check-up. Option A is incorrect as relying solely on the patient's own blood pressure measurements may not be accurate, and it is important for the physician to take their own measurements in order to confirm or refute the patient's reported values. Option C is incorrect as local standards of care should still align with national guidelines, and blood pressure measurements are an important aspect of managing diabetes and preventing associated complications. Option D is incorrect as blood pressure monitoring should be continued at all follow-up appointments in order to track any changes or trends.

We refer to ASCVD Risk Estimator Plus from ACC for help. According to the guidelines, blood pressure should be measured at every visit for patients with diabetes. While the patient has been monitoring their blood pressure at home, it is still important to confirm these measurements in the office and to monitor for any changes over time. Option (A) and (C) are incorrect as blood pressure measurement is a standard of care and standardized national guidelines exist. Option (D) is incorrect as blood pressure should be monitored at follow-up appointments.

We refer to medical practice guidelines for help. According to the American Diabetes Association, blood pressure measurement is part of the standard of care for every patient with diabetes mellitus at every visit, regardless of their blood pressure diary. Therefore, the physician has to measure the patient’s blood pressure to ensure appropriate management of diabetes complications.

Blood pressure measurement is a standard of care for any person with diabetes mellitus who presents for a check-up, regardless of the patient’s own measurements. Therefore, option B is correct. Option A is incorrect because ignoring blood pressure measurement at a check-up can lead to missed diagnoses and complications. Option C is incorrect because local standards of care cannot differ significantly from national standards of care. Option D is incorrect because blood pressure should be measured at each regular follow-up appointment for a diabetic patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A patient with type 2 diabetes is at an increased risk for hypertension and hypertension is a major risk factor for cardiovascular disease, retinopathy, nephropathy, and stroke. Therefore, blood pressure is recommended to be measured at every visit for a patient with diabetes mellitus. It’s important to note that a patient's self-measured blood pressure may not always be accurate, and the physician may need to measure it to confirm the readings. Option (C) is incorrect as local standards of care should not differ from national standards of care in measuring blood pressure for patients with diabetes mellitus. Option (D) is incorrect as regularly measuring blood pressure is important for ongoing management of patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.

We refer to the American Diabetes Association's Standards of Medical Care in Diabetes for help. The standard of care for patients with diabetes mellitus includes measuring blood pressure at every routine visit. Therefore, the physician must measure the patient's blood pressure even though they have been measuring it at home and providing diary readings. The physician can compare the patient's blood pressure measurements to the national standards of care for patients with diabetes mellitus.

We refer to guidelines from the American Diabetes Association for help. According to the guidelines, blood pressure measurements should be taken at every routine diabetes visit or at least twice a year in patients with normal blood pressure. As such, the physician should measure the patient's blood pressure because it is a standard of care for any person with diabetes mellitus who presents for a check-up. The local standards of care or the patient's personal measurement diary should not affect the physician's duty to measure blood pressure as the physician needs to compare the patient's blood pressure to national standards of care. It is not true that assessment of blood pressure only needs to be done at the initial visit, as regular monitoring is important.

Blood pressure measurement is a standard of care for patients with diabetes mellitus, as they are at higher risk for hypertension and related complications. The physician should measure the patient's blood pressure, even if the patient keeps a record of their own measurements, to ensure accuracy and provide appropriate management if hypertension is identified.

We refer to UpToDate articles on medicine for help. The American Diabetes Association recommends annual measurement of blood pressure in patients with diabetes mellitus. It is a standard of care and should not be skipped, regardless of the patient’s own measurements. The physician should take the patient's blood pressure.

We refer to UpToDate article on diabetes management for help. Blood pressure measurement is standard of care for any person with diabetes mellitus who presents for a check-up, regardless of whether they measure at home or not. The physician should also check for any white-coat hypertension since the patient is measuring it at home. Option (C) is incorrect because local standards of care should align with the national standards of care. Option (D) is incorrect because blood pressure should be assessed at every follow-up appointment.
